results.title: Thelma and Louise (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Ridley Scott, Mimi Polk and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Fasten your seatbelts as two of Hollywood’s hottest women rev it up and take it on the road! When unhappy housewife Thelma (Geena Davis) and her wisecracking friend Louise (Susan Sarandon) decide to take a break from their lives, they embark on a trip that leads to a tragic incident at a roadside honky tonk. In an instant, their weekend “getaway” becomes just that as they flee across the American southwest with the police one step behind. A classic twist of the usual “buddy-outlaw” movie, where men are most often the unlikely heroes, this film has a charming, refreshing and triumphant outlook. Co-starring Harvey Keitel.

results.title: Their first year
results.creator_credit: Roland Feven, Phillip Sattin and Eothen Films
results.brief_description: Advice for mothers on child care during the first year of life. Observes several mothers and babies and gives guidance on such subjects as bathing, breast and bottle feeding, teething, potting, sickness after meals, the “three month colic”, immunization, and hazards in the home. Raises, without trying to resolve, the problem of the psychological impact of a new arrival on older children.

results.title: Zoo baby animals
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Opportunity for children to look behind the scenes at the zoo - to see activities in the kitchen and hospital; how baby animals are fed and cared for by their keepers. Shows many animals in attractive outdoor settings and in “children’s zoo” sections in the famous Lincoln Park and Brookfield Zoos of Chicago. Baby animals featured in the film are the lion, tiger, gorilla, bear, elephant, harbor seal, kudu, llama, Barbary sheep, tapir and baboon.

results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Gerry Hudson, David Hughes, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: This film was made at the Melbourne Zoo and, without commentary, shows the activities - particularly eating - of birds in the air and animals on land and in water. There are some interesting close-ups of parts of animals, eg. the texture of the skin of a hippo and the back of an eagle.

results.title: The Track
results.creator_credit: Michael Cordell, Nick Greenaway, Victoria Pitt, Penny Chapman, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Chapman Pictures and Hilton Cordell Productions
results.brief_description: A 6 part series on the history of the Australian Racing Industry from the different points of view of the jockeys, trainers, bookies, callers, punters and politicians. Horse racing started in the 1700’s to give the developing colony something social and sporting to go to, and was a popular pastime, despite the ban on swearing, fighting, gambling and drinking, and has since developed into a huge industry. Each episode covers a period of time in racing history from 1788 to current racing, and includes interviews with trainers, jockeys and callers of the past. Footage of famous horses includes Phar Lap and Bernborough. Narrated by Tiriel Mora.

results.title: Vision in mathematics: linear programming
results.brief_description: Examines ideas leading to consideration of linear programming, such as the values of various combinations of coins. Also shows the sequence of operations in preparing a linear program for the computer.

results.title: Visages de femmes = Faces of women
results.creator_credit: Desire Ecare and Films de la Lagune
results.brief_description: Twelve years in the making, “Visages de Femmes” is a wonderfully unpredictable and creative look at the financial, sexual and emotional emancipation of African women. The film is a series of episodes linked by a chorus featuring traditional singing and dancing. Ecare’s achievement is to create a visual feast which owes little to colonial models of cinema.

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 5 & 6
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Precious but perishable Due to poor storage in wooden barrels in the middle ages, wine tended to deteriorate quickly. This led to England, the major consumer of the time, importing claret from Bordeaux which was close, and the stronger, longer lasting, malmsey and sack (sherry) from the eastern Mediterranean and Spain. “The slopes of gold” looks at the rise of the great vineyards of Burgundy where each tiny vineyard produces individual wine whose qualities are determined by the geology of the area.

results.title: Setting the scene: the Metropolis case
results.brief_description: A limited edition DVD presented exclusively to visitors of the ‘Setting the Scene’ exhibition at the Australian Centre of the Moving Image, Federation Square, Melbourne. featuring ‘The Metropolis case’ and special bonus material (‘The Restoration’ and ‘Photo Gallery’).

results.title: Zero [DVD] (D)
results.brief_description: This is the debut feature of surrealist avant-garde filmmaker James Fotopoulos. A work that oscillates between scenes of serenity and ones of utter depravity, “Zero” tells the story of a man (Matthew Buckley) sliding into absolute isolation, accompanied by pornography, mental illness and disease. In his drab apartment, with its exposed pipes and austere furnishings, the man has pasted explicit pornographic and medical images. He also has collected an array of jars that hold specimens of tumours and animals. The man seeks intimacy and release from his seclusion but his only source of contact is his extensive collection of pornographic magazines that he pours over and speaks to in an array of demonic monologues, whilst a gruesome cyst grows on his forearm. The man’s masturbatory fantasies lead to him romancing the armless upper half of a store mannequin whom he covets. In alternate sequences the man is witnessed strolling through fields and forests, having found a space (perhaps imaginary) in which to reside free from the conflict and poisonous, misogynist, racist ranting of his mind. Fotopoulos’ experimental, minimalist cinema despondently explores the spaces of physical desire and the dark parameters of loneliness. The industrial sound-scape, that marks all of this Midwestern filmmaker’s work, adds to the sense of futility and misanthropy that permeates the unilateral narrative. Music by Tom Nicholl. Features images of pornography and excessive female nudity and medical experimentation. Warning: some scenes may disturb.
